User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.1) Gecko/20061010 Firefox/2.0
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.1) Gecko/20061010 Firefox/2.0

Error: uncaught exception: Permission denied to set property Window.RegExp
Source File: https://login.live.com/login.srf?wa=wsignin1.0&rpsnv=10&checkda=1&ct=1161219319&rver=4.0.1531.0&wp=LBI&wreply=http:%2F%2Fwww.msn.com%2F&lc=1033&id=1184
Line: 1

Home page is still set, but this Hijacks your opening page

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. restart firefox 2
2.
3.

Actual Results:  
does not go to your home page, instead goes to

Error: uncaught exception: Permission denied to set property Window.RegExp
Source File: https://login.live.com/login.srf?wa=wsignin1.0&rpsnv=10&checkda=1&ct=1161219319&rver=4.0.1531.0&wp=LBI&wreply=http:%2F%2Fwww.msn.com%2F&lc=1033&id=1184
Line: 1

Expected Results:  
should have gone to home page

Error: uncaught exception: Permission denied to set property Window.RegExp
Source File: https://login.live.com/login.srf?wa=wsignin1.0&rpsnv=10&checkda=1&ct=1161219319&rver=4.0.1531.0&wp=LBI&wreply=http:%2F%2Fwww.msn.com%2F&lc=1033&id=1184

comments.text: Looks like it is msn itself who is hijacking msn and sending me to some sort of automatic login variation.  Firefox 2 did nothing to stop or warn of this hijacking, and my home page value never changed to reflect this.  If I click on the home page icon I go to the correct home page value.  Very weird.  But I think I now know how to undue it - need to restore the default home page, then restore my home page to msn.com.  If msn can do this crap there may be a loophole that someone malicious can take advantage of.
comments.author: ajgphd@alum.mit.edu
comments.creator: ajgphd@alum.mit.edu

Firefox 2 did nothing to stop or warn of this hijacking, and my home page value never changed to reflect this.  If I click on the home page icon I go to the correct home page value.  Very weird.  But I think I now know how to undue it - need to restore the default home page, then restore my home page to msn.com.  If msn can do this crap there may be a loophole that someone malicious can take advantage of.
